When aliens reveal their presence, it probably won't be like War of the Worlds. Why would a species with the ability to travel lightyears to visit a planet just knock down the door and say hi while everyone's eating dinner? Even though they'd likely be able to dominate us with force, barging in like that creates too many unpredictable variables that are out of their control, and their agenda runs the risk of being less efficient or possibly even failing. Independence Day is an accurate example of what could happen to a well-prepared alien race who makes their presence known abruptly and aggressively. A sufficiently intelligent species would probably make sure they had total control over our awareness of them, and then keep their presence hidden most or all of the time. The aliens are probably already here. They're either programming us slowly into a passive acceptance of them and have a big reveal planned; or, they're completing their agenda under our noses and plan on leaving without us ever knowing they were here. Maybe the real situation is that the aliens have been here and left a while ago.

In the Fermi paradox it might seem that we are 'special' or more intelligent but if you look at it in a different way. There are inter-galactic filters.
For example nuclear war, inventing fire, surviving the ice age and the closest filter we have is planet self-destruction and that it could wipe out the race.
But, it is still scary even if we are behind or more modern than other living beings because if we are behind then we are then expecting something, a challenge. And if we are more better then we are sure to expect something more challenging that could end us all.
Another part of the Fermi paradox is that more 'better' cilivisations don't appear near us because they have died at a filter.
Eg: an alien might have invented a way of getting better power but a riskier cost of destroying us all (like coal powerplants).

I don't get it why the Fermi paradox is a paradox. Travelling to even the nearest star would take years. And who says that it is actually possible to create propulsion systems that can reach a considerable fraction of light speed? And even if they can reach 20 percent light speed, proxima centauri would need 22.5 years to get there. 22.5 years of living in an enclosed capsule with the need to bring either all the food oder to create techniques to make plants grow. And this is the nearest star. Everything else would get into the "hundreds of years" and it would need individuals to breed and to teach their children how to fly the space craft. Who would want to live his entire life on a tin capsule in space? And it would need generations of them. 1000 years of space travel like 30 generations or so? So probably it's not a paradox at all but just a simple consequence of the vast distances of the universe that it is not common to be visitied. Maybe in another part it already happened because by chance two planets with intelligent life were not so far away from each other? But otherwise, I don't find it so paradox that we don't get visitors which had travelled 1500 years from their home world, to be honest..

I figured out how much 1 cubic metre of water  (average) and it is £3. Then I did 3 pound times 1,132,000,000,000 to get £3,396,000,000,000 .


Step two is to find out how much on average 1m³ of land costs, which is £19,439 at the most expensive, so I'll run with that. Then we find out how many cubic metres is on Earth. Which is 1,000,000,000,000. We times them together to get £19,439,000,000,000,000. Add them together and you get…




£22,396,000,000,000! God that's a lot. To put it into perspective, there is £62,335,920,000.00 of money on Earth! I know I didn't include farm and allot of other things, and this is a rough estimate but this is my answer.

Actually the monkey selfies are slightly different than shown here. The camera was not stolen. The camera was set up in a way that a monkey can easily trigger it and the photographer showed how the triggering mechanism works. The monkeys mimiced the photographer. It was deliberately set up that way.

Therefore, in my opinion, the photographer should have the rights for those photographs. He set the whole thing up and "used" a monkey as a trigger.

If he does not hold the rights to that photograph, what happens to automated speed cameras? It is the driver who triggers the photograph. Does the driver own the rights and therefore could prevent them from being used against him/her? Can the driver demand compensation from using his copyrighted photograph in the court?

How about security cameras with movement detectors? Moving triggers the recording. Does the burglar own the filmed material?

I would say no. If a system is set up in a way that something triggers it to start filming or taking photographs, the one who set it up holds the rights.

There's a mistake at 7:09. The Fermi Paradox isn't about why haven't aliens visited us. It's about why we can't see aliens-- especially when they should be pretty darn visible. Here's why.

Any logical civilization will expand from its home world into the rest of its system, but it won't focus on other planets. Instead, it will convert comets and asteroids into trillions of habitable rotating cylinders. These are called Dyson swarms, and they're are clearly visible and obviously artificial. Even one such system will be visible from anywhere else in the galaxy.

But it doesn't take ultimate technology to build a swarm. It just takes fusion engines and automated builder bots. Our own species is pretty close to cracking both -- it's entirely likely we'll finish our own Dyson sphere before the millennium is out. Just think: from the rise of agriculture to interstellar travel, in a mere 15,000 years.

The Universe is nearly 15,000 million years old -- time enough to tear it all down and start again and again and again more times than you could bear to count. If we're on the cusp of interstellar dominion, complete with giant signs advertising our existence to everyone billions of light years around... why hasn't anyone else done it first?

That's the Fermi Paradox.

Maybe I should document my experiences. Many years ago I used to trade small pieces of bread for acorns with my local squirrel scurry.  I would sit on the porch and throw out a couple pieces. After many weeks the squirrels would come closer and closer.  They would wait for me to throw the bread. When I didn't have any bread for a couple days, one of them got the idea to bring an acorn about five feet away and left it, ran away. Then brought another one and left it also. I got some bread, came back and the third time he left another acorn I threw bread right at him. Pretty soon more than a few would come up about five feet or so leave acorns and wait. I would even find acorns on the porch if I missed a day or two. Sadly many of the oaks in the yard have been blown down or aged to the point they don't produce many acorns.  I think I might try this again, this time with camera in hand.

Considering how one sided most currency conversions are; I'd say if aliens DID consider buying Earth and offered currency, we shouldn't say that their money is worthless. Rather, we should try to equate it to our own and ask how much of theirs is a "living wage" persé. Assuming their lifestyle is similar to ours and consists of education, occupation, shopping, home life, etc.; we could find the equivalent in our currency.

Like how a person earning $12/hr in an 8 hour/day job 5 days/week for a month would get $1534 as the paycheck. That converted to Indonesian Rupiah is 20,091,565. For a single man or woman in Indonesia, $300/month is enough for a living wage, yet we view our currency as being so much more valuable that if an American were to take his paycheck to Indonesia, that could very well be the last paycheck he needs for a long time.

I think advanced civilizations avoid us, because we are too primitive. Making contact by advanced civilizations would completely alter the development of a primitive civilization. On the other side we can't detect them, because 1) Space if just too large and we spend way too little resources to have any statistical chance. 2 ) AFAIK we searching for radio waves. We seriously started using radio waves 60+ odd years ago on a large scale, and soon after realized it is not a long term solution for communications. Even communicating with a rover on Mars takes 20+ minutes one way. So any advanced civilization would also, if at all, only used radio for a very brief time in their existence. As for hostile aliens that sweep through and devour everything..1) They probably never survived their version of the Cuban missile crisis, if they are that aggressive, and 2) If they did, they would quickly have made too many enemies among existing races.

The systems of property law and taxation adopted by all societies violate the moral principle that the earth is the equal birthright of all persons. Warfare has served to divide the planet into regions controlled by specific groups who claim (unjustly) sovereign control over that portion of the planet. Future wars are likely to be fought over territory and control over the resources contained therein. it is not unthinkable that such wars will be wars of annihilation given our past patterns of behavior.

In a world where our species continues to act as though some are chosen and others are intruders, there is little chance of global peace. Hatreds are ancient. Intolerance is deep. The weapons that cause death and destruction are all-powerful.

The last real change to change the course of history occurred in the late 19th century, when the American political economist achieved worldwide acclaim with his attack on landed privilege as the cause of poverty. His book 'Progress and Poverty' sold millions of copies and was translated into many of the world's languages. However, he died in 1897, leaving the fledgling social and political movement he initiated to falter and face near-extinction with the start of the First World War.

Thoughtful people around the world need to revisit the insights and message of Henry George. In my humble opinion, the path he urged is the only path that will save us from ourselves.

My reasoning for the Fermi paradox: distance.

Consider, that the closest star to Sol (our Sun for the uncultured), is Proxima Centari, at 4.2 light years away. 
This means that whenever we look at that star, we are really looking at how it was 4.2 years ago, and even if we could travel at the speed of light, it would take 4.2 years to get there.
This also applies to radio or micro waves, so communications would be 4.2 years out of date by the time they reached Earth, and careful calculations would have to be taken to ensure such transmissions would actually hit earth, which would no longer be in the same place it was 4.2 years ago - earth is comparatively small, and it would be easy for a signal to miss the Earth.

Now consider that only a fraction of planets with favorable conditions for life would likely develop it, and the potential distance between us increases up to the order of billions of light years. Even if Aliens could travel at light speed, it would take years, decades, centuries, millennia, etc to get to earth, and they would still have no way of knowing we were even here in the first place, as telescopes can't see such details at such distances.
 Even if we managed to receive electromagnetic signals and send them back, the delay in this conversation would be years.

The sad truth might be that they ARE there, but we simply have no way of knowing, both parties wondering why we are alone when we just can't get a response from the stars.

Thus it stands to reason that they cannot communicate effectively without actually getting here, which would require either faster than light travel (At present, not believed to be scientifically possible) or alternatively the ability to travel in a distance shorter than a straight line (spacial folding, wormholes, etc, which is also flaky scientifically), and to just assume Sapient extraterrestrial life has developed it (if it even is possible) may simply be too big of an assumption.

Since plants were the first large organisms to propagate on the surface and oceans of this planet, shouldn't we consider the earth to be "property" of the natural forces which govern life itself here? Without those plants, we could not exist. Perhaps we're simply subletting the planet from the plants whose existence allows our own?

If anything, we should consider that all our vital energy, that which keeps our bodies out of thermodynamic equilibrium with the solar thermodynamic system, comes from plants, which produce everything we rely on, from food to fuel to medicine and cloth, structures and, of course, the maintenance of our oxygen-rich atmosphere.

They do all the "work" to keep our planet habitable, even despite us as a species kind of wrecking the place. 

I'd like to think that if anyone "owns" the planet, it is the entities which maintain it as a habitable environment, and those entities are almost all plants of every kind.

And we know that the plants are integral to our continued survival, because our research, as a species, into the colonization of other worlds has heavily involved finding out whether or not we can bring terrestrial plants with us into outer space, and if they could adapt to other worlds.

Some groups of humans also lack this concept of ownership. In south America, for example, there is a group of humans preserved in relative isolation. Anthropologists studying them have found that although they have simple bartering systems, they don't take it as far as the rest of the world. To try and teach them how one item can be worth two of another item the Anthropologist tried to "buy" the chief's hammok to which he replyed, "Where would I sleep?". To them, valuation of goods is related to usefulness. All the raw materials of the Earth are useless if you have no where to live.

Other groups of humans at least had differing concepts of valuation. Native American tribes didn't lack a concept of ownership as commonly believed, but instead there was an idea about "hunting rights". In many tribes you can trade for the right to hunt and fish on land, but that wasn't considered a transfer of ownership. It was closer to a concept of rent.

The fact that humans have demonstrated various ways of approaching the valuation of goods implies that it's not a universal truth. Even between similar ideals of valuation there is no way of knowing if anyone would agree to the same value. Oxygen is, for example, a very deadly gas. If an alien race can't tolerate an oxygen rich atmosphere they would value the Earth along the same lines as a human might value sea of sulfuric acid. Even if the materials are of value, if they have to go through additional measures to extract it that will also decrease the potential value.

PROBABILITY

If we isolate all the elements from our bodies and sell it at market price, and we'll be worth $2000? Dude, I'd wager more. After all, isn't the Whole greater than the Sum of all parts? :P This is precisely why an Computer is worth more than the resources and parts sold separately; you add the time, intelligence and effort spent manufacturing it (just as an object's Mass INCREASES the more you add energy to it by pushing / accelerating / rotating it).

A bunch of proteins and chemicals may be cheap, but if that very specific bunch of proteins and chemicals sold as a fully assembled and functional "brain" that can comprehend the universe? Not so cheap (especially when it's branded by Apple). Now multiply that by the Quadrillions you got from your equations.

If I were to put a price on the Earth, the price tag would read "Priceless". There are just some thigs money can't buy... (I really wish most corporations realized this already -- provided we don't have worse kinds in outer space who have even worse concepts of ownership and bartering, and we're probably already "owned" by species we've never even met. I think we need a new definition for a moon. IAU, I'm looking at you.

I think it should be something along the lines of:

Moon: An object which is gravitationally rounded and orbits a planet or dwarf planet with its orbit cleared of debris and is in an orbit that is stable enough that its apoapsis and periapsis are within one hill sphere diameter of the same height as they were in on the previous orbit. Our moon, Io, Titan, Ganymede, etc.

Dwarf moon: Same as above, but is too small to be gravitationally rounded. Phobos, Deimos, etc.

Minor planetary satellite: Must maintain a stable orbit within their own hill sphere, but need not clear its orbit of debris. The "mini-moons" within Saturn's rings are a good example.

Minor temporary planetary satellite: Must make at least one full orbit of a planet or dwarf planet. Asteroids that get trapped for a few orbits.

No algorithm can be made to assess the value the universe will place on anything. The only constant is that as the universe grows larger and aliens have greater contact with other civilizations, their trade values will also increase.
Take, for example, your Pokeman card collection, if you have one. The cards you have in your possession might not hold much value to us on earth, but to a universe teeming with aliens and cultural collectors, they might be worth a substantial amount. And the fact that you have only 3 of 1 million of  a certain card will be more valuable the more other civilizations come into play who may want to increase their collection of rare Human earth antiquities.
In other words, keep your Pokemon collection. It might be worth something someday....

Hi Michael. Great video as always but I see some quintessential and unequivocal contradictions in the statements that you're trying to assert here. A true worth of a typical item, say gold, is it's material value for whatever use it might have. And you clearly tried to distinguish that an item without a price-tag that can be bartered with superior intelligence because material goods are the only valuables we can offer. But in other sense, we all claim our own self-proclaimed worth because as species adept with millennia of tool-making, till the present day that is, we set our values through the quality we add to the basic materials such as enabling gold to be a supercondutor or making a stable radioactive element. You have to take into account that technology has grown thus far because of the combined inputs of like-minded individuals and coherent efforts summed up over a course of the entire human history however inferior it might seems and the fact that we do not own earth, even more, we might not be the fruits from the loins of the planet at all, rather are festering petulance vindicated for being nuance which I can accept. But aren't all civilized beings criticized like that in their own planets in general elsewhere in the universe? As divided communities of a single species, self-actualization and the urge to instigate and explore requires certain repercussions, which if left unchecked might have catastrophic planetary effects. Disagreements would have devastating actions when attempting to inspire beliefs, imbue way of life and settle differences, which could be the reason why we were not discovered by other intelligent life form. Not just we appear to be mediocre to them but because when the conviction of any anticipatory intelligent being is being questioned, disparities would be settled by waging wars which might lead to complete extermination.

Maybe the reason we haven't been visited is because we are so far away from other planets. An unknown island in the middle of the ocean is not more likely to be visited by us if we do not know about it, even if it is beautiful. If the natives of that island have not developed boats to travel to us, even if they have more advanced businesses and technology due to the isolation, then they will not be able to travel out to us in our islands that are close to each other. It may be hard for one of our explorers travelled out on the ocean, the chances of coming across this small island in a small ocean are very small. We may even find it better just to have trade paths between our known islands rather than go to find new ones. Eventually, we may be able to develop technology to travel to other solar systems, while this small island hasn't. At this point, even if we discover the island, we may have no interest in visiting due to us being able to travel between solar systems, even if the island has beautiful and unique areas and people.

Also, we may be the most advanced planet of the ones near enough to travel. Or they might be on their way, but haven't reached us yet. We can wait forever, they may come or may never come, but we can never truly say aliens don't exist until we have the technology to travel to planets where life can exist and explore their planet.

Finally, I think the selfies should belong to the animals. Anyone that uses it, instead of royalties paid to the owners, should pay the animal in treats.

This vid touched on a subject I have debated before. We are absolutely unique. There is no one else out there just like us. We aren't finger print unique, we are absolute in our uniqueness.  The reason that has come up before for me was in debates about life existing somewhere out there in the universe and how one tries to define life.  Europa may have life (I think it should), but not anything that looks like us.  There is a disconnect because people tend to connote one with the other and then they get confused. Like it was stated in this video, we did not shape our planet, but our planet shaped us. Who I am right now, doing what I am doing right now, is a consequence of the ballad danced by the atoms and molecules since the big bang that led to the environmental pressures to make me who I am doing what I am doing. As I once mentioned in a conversation, if there was a galaxy out there that was exactly like ours, with the stars and planets and debris scattered throughout just as it is in ours, with the same development time and age as ours, then the odds of there being a me in that galaxy typing the words I am saying right now goes up very quick, because we are nothing more than the product of those reactions. In essence, it is like baking a cake. If I do everything the same for two different cakes, the odds of the cakes coming out exactly the same goes up.  Just simply chemistry.  Our uniqueness is amazing, and allows us to say that there is no one like us anywhere else in the universe...most likely. There definitely is intelligent life and definitely life out there, but it will not look anything like anything found on our Earth.  Because of that...we may be nothing more than a zoo to some intelligent life out there.  Just like the giraffe does not know it is in a zoo, we may not know we are in one too. We do have greater intelligence than a giraffe, but the reality is not that we are smart, but that we are smarter than a giraffe and if intelligent life is out there (and it definitely should be) then they are probably smarter than us to have space travel that we are yet to discover.  We can obviously cage the giraffe, chain it and bind it and make it know and feel that it is nothing better than a captive of ours, but whats the fun in that, we want to see them being themselves and for all we know we have the same role for any species smarter than us.  As such I find it fascinating how we are so grand in how tiny we are and how tiny we are in all of our grandeur.  We are both meaningful and meaningless and to me that makes us all uniquely great. We are nothing more than "a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam" yet we are an especially unique mote of dust.

Yeah, the term "moon" really needs to be cleaned up a bit - because although we claim there to be only around 173 known moons in the solar system, by this vague definition, we have to actually also count all the objects that make up the rings of the Gas Giants. Clearly this is just silly, and runs us into problems similar to what we had with classifying planets when it came to Pluto.

Perhaps a better definition would come with the requirement that the orbiting body has enough mass that it has become spherical due to its own gravity, and thus has also stopped tumbling and rotates only around a single axis, and that at remains in a fairly stable orbit, rather than an erratic one that flings it away after a few years. Hell, maybe even with the same caveat as planets, requiring them to have "cleaned out" their own orbit and become its dominant source of mass - though this may have the unfortunate downside of relegating Saturn's ring moons.
This would allow us to keep our precious Moon, without having to go stupid and start naming everything else that has the audacity to orbit a planet.
Still Saturn does give us a precedent, since we do recognize the difference between some of its "moons" and some of its "moonlets", just like we recognize a difference between "planets", "dwarf planets" and "planetesimals" (though, granted, sometimes we're still a bit vague on the last 2).
It'll piss off the people who love Phobos and Deimos, but, ya know.... sod 'em.

Something does need to be done though, and perhaps recognizing that not all natural satellites are "moons" wouldn't be a bad thing.

Ownership, especially of land, isn't actually even shared by all humans. Here in Australia, the indigenous Australians, one of the oldest surviving cultures in the world, didn't possess land or have a bartering system. They didn't fence off sections of the land to farm or build on and this eventually meant that Australia was declared "Terra Nullis" by the English: basically that the continent was uninhabited by humans and free to be claimed by any white culture, because this idea that the land didn't belong to anyone and that sections of land didn't need to be possessed and fenced was so unusual to them they just decided these people weren't "advanced".

So I think ownership must be pretty rare in the universe if, even here on Earth among humans, it is still fairly unique.

A monetary system is completely absurd and utterly ineffective in this day and age. More efficient answers to global issues lay within the technology we now possess. The key word there is "global". The human race has yet to realize, as one single organism, the true "value" of the planet we live on. The sooner that we decide to let down our borders and declare that we are in fact, one single organism entitled to everything our planet has to provide, the sooner we will prosper, and many of the issues we face as a civilization will quickly become obsolete.  It's not a matter of "utopia". We either change or we die. The only dictator in the Universe is Nature, herself. The solutions become quite simple to understand if you truly yearn to establish them, and if you truly educate yourself on the SOURCE of the world's issues rather than the SYMPTOMS. The answers are right in front of us. It's getting people to see and accept them that is the problem. It's unfortunate that the majority of our society doesn't care to change anything until they lose everything and it's too late. Let us be the ones, here and now, to make a difference for generations to come! One solution: research the concept of a Resource-Based Economy.

There's a huge universe out there that has bodies that grew independently of Earth so what we define as life has to be different there. Just something to think about....

I don't remember what this theory is called or who came up with it, but I've heard an explanation for why we haven't encountered alien life that I think is probably pretty accurate:

If you consider the timespan of human evolution and how long we've been at the level of being able to design and construct space fairing vehicles... it's a pretty small blip on the timescale of the universe, ain't it? We don't know how long this period of humanity will last. For all we know, it'll stop as soon as the oil runs out. So probably less than a century from now. And even if we're optimistic and say that we'll invent a new technology for space travel that doesn't require oil, and we keep doing it for centuries... we still wouldn't be able to travel that far, relative to the size of the universe. At the most optimistic, it's unlikely we will ever leave our galaxy. 

But... forget distance. Forget that massive limitation of how small our reach in the universe actually is, even given all the time in the universe... because the biggest limitation is actually just that: timing. Even if we were able to visit every last corner of the universe in one day... that one day would only be one day out of a VAST expanse of time that the universe has existed and will exist....
Yes, it's likely that the universe can harbour intelligent life other than us. But it's incredibly unlikely that we will exist at the same TIME as them.

Odds are, if there is, has been or will be a species of intelligent life elsewhere in the universe, then it's either extinct already or doesn't exist yet. The chances that we would evolve at the exact same time as another intelligent species on a similar planet somewhere, are (appropriately) astronomical.

What we're more likely to find somewhere in the universe is the REMNANTS of an intelligent species from the past. Not one that's still living.

Or we'll find tiny single-celled life that will one day, millions of years from now, evolve into intelligent life. 

But the chances that we''ll find comparable intelligent life to us, who just happen to be in the prime of their evolutionary millennia, just like us, and happen to be reaching the level of space-travel at around the same time as us... it's just very very unlikely.

Surely the value of Earth should not be based on the raw materials, rather what has been done with them. The pyramids for example, if easily transportable, would be priceless, but several thousand tonnes of limestone would be worth far less. The same applies to a computer. Some silicon and other elements, worth reasonably little, are worth far more built together into a usable device: It is worth more than the sum of its components. Surely this logic is applicable to earth as well: if we had the technology, and used all the materials on earth to make a huge intergalactic warship, would it be worth more on an intergalactic market than the huge ball of elements and compounds from which the ship was made? And by this logic is the value of anything infinite, the value based not on what it is made of and the rarity of its components, but how useful the constructed object actually is?

Let's try to shine peace on these religious discussions.

Atheists:
What assures you that science is completely separated from the divine? What tells you that divine entities didn't create science as we know it?

Monotheists:
Who says there is only one god? If there can't be more than one, and to your understanding, all other mythologies ( like the Nordic, the Greek, the Roman) are wrong, what tells you that your religion isn't also wrong?

Now, allow me to present my view.

We are in an Universe created by a divine entity, and in this Universe, anything that happens is due to the divine entity's wish. Science as we know it and science as we still not know it happens because the divine entity wants such. Evolution happens because the divine entity wants it like that. Isn't evolution so logical and apparent? That's because it's divine. Something on such a perfect scale might occur because it's created by a more understanding entity.
Why are there atheists, then? Free will. The divine entity wants all living things in its Universe to be free to choose whatever they do. Whatever they believe will be true to them. Therefore, all your beliefs will come true after you die, so I think of Heaven in one way, I'll go to that heaven. If I don't think of a heaven, fair enough, I won't go to any. 
Why haven't we proved this entity yet? Because it doesn't want to be proven.
Wars? Fruit of the right of choice, free will of the living things.
Sins? Free will causes it.
Multiplicity of religions? There comes the second part. For me, all gods and anti-gods that were ever believed upon exist. Zeus, Quetzalcoatl, Amon Ra, God, Allah, Spaghetti monster, whoever. They exist along with the divine entity, and are part of it. We can only believe in a divine entity if it exists, along with the highest divine entity, the creator (and that's why they can't also be proven). Why are there things in the Bible that are incorrect? Because the Bible is written by men, and men can be corrupt and bias their work torwards their interests. 
I'm a devout Christian, as I praise the chatolic God as my guide on how to life. Most of the principles I use are not from the Old Testament, though, as these works are seemingly more symbolic and biased. I prefer the New Testament, as it presents socially logical instructions and restrictions. Therefore, this God must be a good God.

Protip: 
- Don't be naive
- If you're an atheist, why are you defending your point? In the name of what?
- Don't call people stupid because of their beliefs. If you're then proved wrong, the shame upon you will be smaller.

Interesting video but i'm not sure I agree with your assumption that animals lack communication and enforcement. We simply don't know that. All you can really say is that animals (with some exceptions) don't speak human languages. But that does in no way mean animals do not communicate. Whales and dolphins for example definitely seem to be communicating. Just because we don't understand it doesn't mean they lack it. As for a sense of ownership, give food or a toy to a dog and in most cases it will react if you take it away. Also how do you know animals have no enforcement? It's entirely possible ants are punished for stealing food. Carnivores that live in social structures, for example wolves, have roles. The leader eats the best parts of the animal. If a lower ranked wolf would try to eat that part punishment follows. They certainly seem to have a sense of ownership and rules, there has to be communication for that to work and when an animal 'breaks the rules' they enforce them with punishment.

People keep using the term "aliens" like it means something. It's non-descriptive, like "creatures" is. Extraterrestrial life forms  have never been seen nor proven to exist, so there are no reasons to suspect that any of them are even capable of such feats as space travel, and given a completely different evolutionary origin, there's no reason to believe any such life forms have societal models that relate to any animal group evolved on Earth. Is it possible? Yes. Is it likely? We have no way of measuring the likelihood that anything not-of-this-earth has anything in common with anything from this Earth. Best we have are the building blocks of life on Earth. We semi-know how life was formed, the same processes could happened outside of Earth.

TL;DR
We know nothing about extraterrestrial life, and anything we might speculate is impossible to gain any kind of insight from.

Well that's a coincidence.  I was thinking about this question yesterday in a really round about way. 

At first I started thinking about the butterfly effect and ethics; and how in general ethics is about doing the right thing (oversimplification but I didnt feel like explaining).  Utilitarians especially believe in the fact that every act has a consequence.  Their ethical goal is to maximize happiness with good intents.  Then I thought, in order to truly "do the right thing" you would need to know literally everything, how even the smallest action will affect other actions and outcomes.  On top of that you would need to decide what is the best action to take.  

For one this is an impossible scenario because we cant be expect to know everything. If we did, then there would be an infinite number of decisions we would have to make.  But if we could, making the right decision wouldnt always be easy.  For example, do you kill your neighbor because she is the great great great great grandmother of someone who will eventually become the most prolific mass bomber in history?  Im sure there are more, even more difficult scenarios that I couldnt possibly think of, but maybe there is a difference between right and wrong; and good and bad.  

In any case, there would be big and clear actions you could, like the example before. But how big would an action need to be to have a noticeable or impactful effect? Could it really be things so small as the flap of a butterfly wing? Or would something like your death not really change much? 

Then I started thinking.  Money.  Actions are bound affect money in some way.  One small decision could potentially give rise to a new multi billion dollar company or destroy a current one.  Next I just followed a trail of questions I asked myself.  How much money do our decisions accumulate?  For example, someone did an action that gave rise to the internet.  How much is that worth? How much impact would small thing have? How much over your life? How much do all your decisions add up to?  What is your worth?  How much are the entire population of a country worth?  What would that be if we included all resources, infrastructure, environment, etc?  How much would it be if we considered the entire world?  

So that's how I came to that final question.  The way I see it is worth is determined by value humans have put on things.  We could come up with a number, but to an alien life form the earth could be worthless to them because it may not see value.  For example, would diamonds be of any value to any species besides us?  I can really think of a reason anyone would need to know the worth of the earth for any practical reason, ie buying or selling the earth.  

OK that was my brain just randomly thinking of stuff.  If you read this, sorry I didnt proofread and I know there are some holes in my thought process but I thought it was interesting.  Now I can finally watch the video.

One of the fundamental aspects of Anarcho-capitalism is that fair market trades can enforce themselves without a central power authority to dictate it's rules and control enforcement. This however is not a rudimentary concept freely available to any animal to develop, but rather an evolutionary concept which relies upon a collective knowledge of the system's functionality, if only at a basic level.

It is perhaps true that the lack of communication and thus enforcement is the key to why commerce is nonexistent in other animals. There are, however, parallels between commerce and evolutionary biology I feel, and it's really only once a species overcomes the more basic needs of survival of the fittest that they can develop more complex social systems.

I've said it before. Humans aren't exactly a very externally active race; we have only been to the moon and have only ventured our current ambitions to the edge of our solar system, simply making us a restricted observational species.

Perhaps the biggest restriction upon us, as humans, we are too concerned with internal affairs such as survival, peer to peer exchange etc. in the present day. Yes, we are still trying to survive. Once this survival instinct is no longer a virtue to us and we possess an abundance of resources to satiate this instinct, we can reduce our restrictions and venture out further into space. In the present day, we don't look far enough into the future to determine what we are capable of learning and doing, which can only be succeeded by looking past internal affairs to denominate a common purpose.

But, humans are too selfish a species to conduct such advanced ambition with limited resources and mindset that we currently possess. It's obviously easier said than done.

One of the rare occasions where I knew something before seeing Vsauce. I had just recently read about the monkey selfies, and seen the other adorable animal self-portraits on Wikimedia. It's one of my favourite stories right now. Oh boy, I want to RANT!

My take on the matter is that SO many people are wrong, according to the comments in the news stories. By law, it does NOT matter who owns the equipment, or how much time, money and effort was put into the trip. I am glad that the pictures are in the public domain. I'm sure the monkeys don't mind... hopefully.

The real "losers" are the news agencies who are still paying for the alleged copyright: They could use the pictures for free, but they pay for them to some who don't deserve the money.

I might be a little harsh towards the photographer, and I hope he still manages. But the truth is, he is now very well known, all thanks to this dispute. He could use it to his advantage the best he can. The pictures would not be so famous if he owned the copyright - since that would mean they weren't genuine selfies. It's all a weird paradox.

One problem with the Fermi Paradox is that it asks the question in regards to our own signals from Earth having reached other planets. The problem here is two fold: If you understand the real Universe (the Electric Universe (Thunderbolts Project, check it out)) then you realize our signals may NOT be able to leave our Sun's electromagnetic influence. Also we have no actual idea how old the Universe really is. That means that other aliens who exist right now may not be any more advanced than us at this time.

You don't need enforcement to grant value to material goods.  That line of reasoning would lead you to conclude that all material goods are worthless because you will eventual die or they will degrade. 

I would use this equation in a world in which enforcement exists.

Value of object in $ = "Present Value of Utils Derived from Product over my Lifespan" x "Average Market Value of a Util in $"

In a world in which enforcement does not exist the formula would meerly change to acount for the lack of enforcement.

Value of object in $ = "Value vs. Risk Adversion Function" ( "Present Value of Utils Derived from Product over my Lifespan Given Probablity of the Product Loss", "My Risk Prefferences") x "Average Market Value of a Util in $" - "Cost of Maintaining Control of Product"

Lack of enforcement will definately decrease the value of a good in comparision to a service.  But it does not automatically make it valueless.

What kills a market in which value exists is stickness.  If the cost of interacting in market is higher than the expected net benefit of trading in the market, then the market will never form.

These assumptions are not even close to the estimation of earth's actual price. Earth's value is not just the sum pf it's parts. (And even if so, what about the value of the work required to extract goods out of it?) There are artifacts, rare formations and things that we have no idea that exist, that would most likely have some ranking values. Much higher than the elements that makes them.
And currency is a dynamic thing. Wouldn't the selling of earth, or, slightly more "reasonable" scenario of estimating it's price for say insurance purposes, paradoxically have an impact on it's price?
The value of things is determined mainly by the demand. Popcorn at the cinema would cost way more than in Walmart. Same goes for water in concerts. Having no other alternative, selling earth wouldn't be an option for any possible price unless the sellers would be able to actually live without it.
